Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Expectation2: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation2: They notice the need to use protective equipment and follow hygiene steps more consistently.
Story: As I sat at the kitchen table, my stepbrother nudged me, grinning as our parents tossed around ideas for the weekend. “You’re coming with us, right?” he asked, and everyone looked at me expectantly. I wanted to say yes, to be part of the family, to not seem distant or uninterested. But my mind kept drifting to my other job—the one I’d just come from, where I scrubbed floors and sanitized surfaces as a housekeeping cleaner. I remembered the supervisor’s stern warning earlier: “You must always use gloves and masks, no exceptions. We can’t risk anyone’s health.” I’d noticed some coworkers skipping steps, and I knew I should set an example, especially with flu season starting. But if I joined the family outing, I’d have to rush from work, maybe not even have time to shower or change, and I worried about bringing germs home. My family expected me to be present, to laugh and relax with them, but my job demanded vigilance and strict hygiene. I felt torn, my heart pulled in two directions, unsure how to meet both sets of expectations without letting someone down.
